metadata.case_name: Tata Iron & Steel Co. Ltd., Indian Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. & Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. v. State of Bihar

facts.text: The three companies who are the appellants own certain mines in Bihar.
Tata Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. has taken on lease iron-ore mines at Noamundi in Singhbhum district, extracts iron-ore utilised in factory at Jamshedpur for making iron & steel.
Indian Iron & Steel Co. Ltd. holds mining concessions for iron and manganese ore at Gua and Monoharpur in Singhbhum district, ore utilised for manufacture at Burnpur and Kulti in Burdwan district.
Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. has taken on lease mines in Singhbhum district, ore manufactured into copper and copper products at factory at Moubhandar.
Ore mined by appellants is not sold as such but utilised for production of finished products which appellants sell.

Tata Iron & Steel Co. was assessed to cess on ore mined till 1926, sold some ore in 1926, assessed thereafter on assumed profit of 12 as. per ton upto 1939-40, then Re. 1 per ton, varied to Rs. 1/4/- per ton in 1950-51, for 1954-55 assessed at Rs. 4/7/- per ton.
Company appealed to Deputy Commissioner contending no liability as no sale of ore, Deputy Commissioner rejected but remanded for enquiry on cost of extraction.
Revision to Commissioner Chota Nagpur rejected, further revision to Board of Revenue rejected on May 12, 1959.
Writ petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 to Patna High Court, dismissed on February 18, 1960, leave under Art. 133 granted.
Similar facts and proceedings for other appellants, writs dealt together.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellants could be said to have derived annual net profits from the mines when the ore mined is not sold as such but utilised for production of finished products which are sold.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.6 read with s.72, tax is on annual net profits derived from mine; profit arises only when extracted ore is sold and amount realised exceeds cost of extraction; sale of ore essential; no profit when ore used in own production as single integrated undertaking; cannot trade with self.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Cess Act ss.5,6,72; Styles v. New York Life Insurance Co.; Thomas v. Richard Evans; Ostime v. Pontypridd; Kikabhai Premchand v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: Act provides for beneficial occupation for land but not for mines, indicating no charge without actual profit receipt.
No machinery for cases where ore not sold; for copper ore no market price.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Cess Act; Colquhoun v. Brooks

respondent_arguments.text: S.5 creates charge on immovable property, ss.6,72 provide measure; mine liable as immovable property.

court_reasoning.text: Profit from mine can exist even if ore not sold as such but converted to finished product sold; profit embedded in overall profit; can disintegrate profits of integrated business for tax on specific activity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for sale of ore itself; processing ore before sale still yields mine profit; factual profit from mining reflected in end product sale.

court_reasoning.text: Principle 'no profit from self' not applicable as no fictional sale; disintegration for attributing profit to mining activity implicit in s.6.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Kikabhai as withdrawal lost to business; here ore transformed and sold.

court_reasoning.text: Annual value for land includes beneficial occupation, analogous but not excluding mine profits without sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words of charging provision cover appellants.

court_reasoning.text: Machinery exists via ss.72-76; Collector ascertains profits or uses 6% of value.

holdings.text: Appellants liable to cess on annual net profits from mines even if ore not sold but used in manufacturing finished products sold.

precedents_cited.case_name: Styles v. New York Life Insurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: No one can make profit out of himself.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thomas v. Richard Evans Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Person cannot make profit out of himself; saves money but no profit.
Identity of source and recipient prevents profits.
No fictional profit from self-sale; unreal to separate business from owner.
Exceptions to no trade with self; profit from own consumption possible.

precedents_cited.case_name: CIT Bombay v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka
Doors Tea Co. Ltd. v. CIT West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Value of own produce used in business is income.

precedents_cited.case_name: CIT Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Apportionment of income under specific Acts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. Ltd. v. CIT Madras
CIT Madras v. Diwan Bahadur S.L. Mathias
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot arbitrarily cut business; entire profit taxed.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Cess Act, 1880 (Bengal Act IX of 1880)
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposition of cess on annual net profits from mines; assessment procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petitions to High Court; leave for appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeals against imposition of cess under Bengal Cess Act on profits from mines where ore not sold but used in manufacturing dismissed; appellants liable as profit from mining exists and can be ascertained.

key_quotes.text: "It is unreal and artificial to separate the business from its owner and treat them as if they were separate entities trading with each other and then by means of a fictional sale introduce a fictional profit which in truth and in fact is non-existent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Kikabhai, explaining no self-profit but distinguished here.

key_quotes.text: "The profit from the mining operation and the winning of the mineral is embedded in the profit realised from the sale of the end product."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for allowing mine profit attribution.

key_quotes.text: "The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs."
key_quotes.speaker: court
